content.description: The route starts on an easy sloping ledge beneath the main crack. As the crack transitions to vertical, the difficulty increases, but the face is featured next to the crack with good footholds. Midway up the route, the crack runs up the middle of a 90-degree corner. There is a good place to rest before liebacking up this section. The crack transitions to horizontal towards the top and requires some armbars and use of small footholds on the polished face.
content.protection: A standard rack. There is a bolted anchor with rappel rings at the top.
content.location: Splitter is the northmost crack on the East-facing side of the face.

content.description:
Ratatouille was named for the large amount of rat poop at the start of the route.

Go up the offwidth, and use the small crack to the left as needed. Go to the right of the block in the crack. Once on top of the block, follow the hand crack to the top of the crack and a large ledge. You can top out, but it is more of a scramble through brush and loose rock.

A toprope can be set from a stout tree, but it will require around 30m of rope to extend the anchor over the lip.
content.location: This route starts at the leftmost side of The Perch. There is a wide offwidth crack at the start with a large block above the offwidth.

content.description: The Perch Highline is approximately 80 feet long and 50 feet off the ground. About 65 feet are walkable if you want to avoid no-fall terrain. Over 100 feet of webbing is recommended for rigging. The views from the line are great, but hauling gear up to The Perch is hard work, and there are more accessible highlines on the base.
content.protection: 3 bolts with quicklinks and a tree.
content.location:
The highline stretches across a gully between The Perch and a rock formation to the north.

There is a bolted anchor on the rock formation at GPS coordinates 38.99557, -104.90971. You can get to the bolts by hiking up the gully and scrambling up the rocks on the right. The second anchor point is a tree directly across from the bolted anchor. The tree anchor should be placed about 10 feet up the tree to create a level line. A picture shows both anchor points.

Tensioning from the bolted anchor is easiest, since the tree is on the side of the steep gully.

content.description:
This route is named after a cross cemented at the top of the Perch.

The bottom of the route starts by climbing around a small overhang and getting established in the handwidth crack. The bottom section can be skipped by traversing from

Splitter

on two parallel cracks.

The crack stays consistent for the next few moves but begins to widen and is body width towards the top. Once the crack ends, transition to using holds on the face and the seam. There is limited gear placement at the top.
content.protection: A standard rack. There is a bolted anchor with rappel rings at the top.
content.location:
Crucifixion is to the left of

Splitter

. See The Perch map for all route locations.
